Line 273: Line 273:
==Deaths==
==Deaths==
[[File:Casualties of the 2011 Egyptian protest 1.png|thumb|A protester casualty on 29 January]]
[[File:Casualties of the 2011 Egyptian protest 1.png|thumb|A protester casualty on 29 January]]
â
Before the protests began, six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported.<ref name="Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast">{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|work=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Mohammed Farouk Hassan">{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians Set Themselves Ablaze After Tunisia Unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elaosboa.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=18 January 2011|work=[[El-Aosboa]] (newspaper)|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Ahmed Hashim El-Sayyid2">{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/nphotos/slideshow/photo//110118/ids_photos_wl/r3428700330.jpg/|title=Mother of Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed|author=[[Staff writer]]|date=18 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]] (via ''[[Yahoo! News]]'')|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> By January 28, three days since country-wide protests had ensued, the death toll from the violence between protestors and riot police had risen to 54 dead and 1,000 injured.<ref name="asianews1"/> By the next day, the total number of those killed rose to at least 102,<ref name=autogenerated2/><ref name=sky-2011-01-30/><ref name="haaretz1">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/death-toll-in-egypt-protests-reaches-five-as-anti-government-riots-persist-1.339392|title=Death Toll in Egypt Protests Reaches Five as Anti-Government Riots Persist – Demonstration Organizers Say Facebook, the Main Site Used by Demonstrators, Has Become Only Partially Accessible; Government Denies Targeting Social Networks|work=[[Haaretz]]|author=Issacharoff, Avi|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="haaretz1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/us-egypt-protests-deaths-idUSTRE70R86L20110128|title=13 Killed in Egypt's Suez, 1,030 Wounded in Cairo|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> many of whom had been shot.<ref name=AlJazeera29th1pm/> The dead included at least 10 policemen, 3 of whom were killed in [[Rafah]].<ref name=autogenerated2/> 2,000 were reported injured.<ref name="reuters3"/> The same day, an employee of the [[Azerbaijan]]i embassy in Egypt was killed while returning home from work in Cairo;<ref name="bloomberg1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/azerbaijani-embassy-worker-shot-dead-in-egypt-ministry-says.html|title=Azerbaijani Embassy Worker Shot Dead in Egypt, Ministry Says|author=Agayev, Zulfugar|work=[[Bloomberg]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> the next day Azerbaijan sent a plane to evacuate citizens<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/politics/1820813.html|title=Ambassador: Embassy Will Continue Providing Necessary Help to Azerbaijanis in Egypt}}</ref> and opened a criminal investigation into the death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/society/1821118.html|title=Prosecutor General's Office Files Lawsuit on Murder of Accountant of Azerbaijani Embassy in Egypt|date=31 January 2011}}</ref>
+
  +
Leading up to the protests, at least six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself on fire in downtown Cairo.<ref name="Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast">{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|work=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> These cases were inspired by, and began exactly one month after, the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia triggering the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising]]. Six instances have been reported, including acts by Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,<ref name="Abdou Abdel-Moneim">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Farouk Hassan,<ref name="Mohammed Farouk Hassan">{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians Set Themselves Ablaze After Tunisia Unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mohammed Ashour Sorour,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elaosboa.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=18 January 2011|work=[[El-Aosboa]] (newspaper)|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed who later died from his injuries.<ref name="Ahmed Hashim El-Sayyid2">{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/nphotos/slideshow/photo//110118/ids_photos_wl/r3428700330.jpg/|title=Mother of Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed|author=[[Staff writer]]|date=18 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]] (via ''[[Yahoo! News]]'')|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
The death toll from the violence had risen to 54 dead and 1,000 injured by 28 January.<ref name="asianews1"/> As of 29 January, at least 102 people were known to have died,<ref name=autogenerated2/><ref name=sky-2011-01-30/><ref name="haaretz1">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/death-toll-in-egypt-protests-reaches-five-as-anti-government-riots-persist-1.339392|title=Death Toll in Egypt Protests Reaches Five as Anti-Government Riots Persist – Demonstration Organizers Say Facebook, the Main Site Used by Demonstrators, Has Become Only Partially Accessible; Government Denies Targeting Social Networks|work=[[Haaretz]]|author=Issacharoff, Avi|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="haaretz1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/us-egypt-protests-deaths-idUSTRE70R86L20110128|title=13 Killed in Egypt's Suez, 1,030 Wounded in Cairo|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> many or most shot.<ref name=AlJazeera29th1pm/> The dead included at least 10 policemen, 3 of whom were killed in [[Rafah]].<ref name=autogenerated2/>
  +   +
By 29 January, 2,000 people were known to be injured.<ref name="reuters3"/> The same day, an employee of the [[Azerbaijan]]i embassy in Egypt was killed while returning home from work in Cairo;<ref name="bloomberg1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/azerbaijani-embassy-worker-shot-dead-in-egypt-ministry-says.html|title=Azerbaijani Embassy Worker Shot Dead in Egypt, Ministry Says|author=Agayev, Zulfugar|work=[[Bloomberg]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> the next day Azerbaijan sent a plane to evacuate citizens<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/politics/1820813.html|title=Ambassador: Embassy Will Continue Providing Necessary Help to Azerbaijanis in Egypt}}</ref> and opened a criminal investigation into the death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/society/1821118.html|title=Prosecutor General's Office Files Lawsuit on Murder of Accountant of Azerbaijani Embassy in Egypt|date=31 January 2011}}</ref>
Funerals for the dead on the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January.<!--from tv--> Hundreds of mourners gathered for the funerals calling for Mubarak's removal.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nolan, Dan|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html|title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt – The Bereaved Families Were Joined by Throngs of Demonstrators Calling for an End to President Hosni Mubarak's Rule|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> By 1 February, the protests had left at least 125 people dead,<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8293442/Egypt-crisis-country-braced-for-march-of-a-million.html|title=Egypt Crisis: Country Braced for 'March of a Million' – A 'March of a Million' Against the Egyptian Regime Has Been Called for Tuesday in Alexandria After One Was Announced in Cairo and All Train Services Were Cancelled, an Aide to Dissident Mohamed ElBaradei Said|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=31 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> although UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Navi Pillay]] stated that as many as 300 people may have died in anti-government unrest in Egypt according to a report by Human Rights Watch. This unconfirmed tally included 80 HRW-verified deaths at two Cairo hospitals, 36 in Alexandria, and 13 in the port city of Suez, amongst others;<ref name="latimes1">{{cite web|author=1 February 2011 |  9:48 am |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html |title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="allvoices1">{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8060066-egypt-unrest-claimed-about-300-lives-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-navi-pillay|title=Egypt Unrest Claimed About 300 Lives – UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillay|publisher=Allvoices.com|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="haaretz2">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/un-human-rights-chief-300-reported-dead-in-egypt-protests-1.340583?localLinksEnabled=false|title=UN Human Rights Chief: 300 Reported Dead in Egypt Protests|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> over 3,000 people were also reported as injured.<ref name="latimes1"/><ref name="allvoices1"/><ref name="haaretz2"/>
Funerals for the dead on the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January.<!--from tv--> Hundreds of mourners gathered for the funerals calling for Mubarak's removal.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nolan, Dan|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html|title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt – The Bereaved Families Were Joined by Throngs of Demonstrators Calling for an End to President Hosni Mubarak's Rule|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> By 1 February, the protests had left at least 125 people dead,<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8293442/Egypt-crisis-country-braced-for-march-of-a-million.html|title=Egypt Crisis: Country Braced for 'March of a Million' – A 'March of a Million' Against the Egyptian Regime Has Been Called for Tuesday in Alexandria After One Was Announced in Cairo and All Train Services Were Cancelled, an Aide to Dissident Mohamed ElBaradei Said|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=31 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> although UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Navi Pillay]] stated that as many as 300 people may have died in anti-government unrest in Egypt according to a report by Human Rights Watch. This unconfirmed tally included 80 HRW-verified deaths at two Cairo hospitals, 36 in Alexandria, and 13 in the port city of Suez, amongst others;<ref name="latimes1">{{cite web|author=1 February 2011 |  9:48 am |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html |title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="allvoices1">{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8060066-egypt-unrest-claimed-about-300-lives-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-navi-pillay|title=Egypt Unrest Claimed About 300 Lives – UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillay|publisher=Allvoices.com|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="haaretz2">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/un-human-rights-chief-300-reported-dead-in-egypt-protests-1.340583?localLinksEnabled=false|title=UN Human Rights Chief: 300 Reported Dead in Egypt Protests|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> over 3,000 people were also reported as injured.<ref name="latimes1"/><ref name="allvoices1"/><ref name="haaretz2"/>
